Reduction (DPV 7.1)

If any subroutine for task QQQï»¿ can also be used to solve PPPï»¿ , we say PPPï»¿ reduces to QQQï»¿. Often, PPPï»¿ is solvable by a single call to QQQï»¿â€™s subroutine, which means any instance xxxï»¿ of PPPï»¿ can be transformed into an instance yyyï»¿ of QQQï»¿ such that P(x)P (x)P(x)ï»¿ can be deduced from Q(y)Q(y)Q(y)ï»¿

Reductions enhance the power of algorithms: Once we have an algorithm for problem Q (which could be shortest path, for example) we can use it to solve other problems.

Graphs

How is a graph represented?

Adjacency matrix

We represent a graph by an adjacency matrix, let there be n=âˆ£Vâˆ£n = |V|n=âˆ£Vâˆ£ï»¿ vertices v1,â€¦,vnv_1, \dots, v_nv1â€‹,â€¦,vnâ€‹ï»¿

For an undirected graph the matrix is symmetric since an edge {u,v}\{u, v\}{u,v}ï»¿ can be taken in either direction

The presence of a particular edge can be cheked in constant time, but it takes O(n2)O(n^2)O(n2)ï»¿ space.

Adjacency List

With size proportional to the number of edges, consists of âˆ£Vâˆ£|V|âˆ£Vâˆ£ï»¿ linked lists, one per vertex. The linked list for vertex uuuï»¿ holds the names of vertices to which uuuï»¿ has an outgoing edge.

Total size of the data structure is O(âˆ£Eâˆ£)O(|E|)O(âˆ£Eâˆ£)ï»¿ but checking for an edge is no longer constant time(requires sifting through uuuï»¿â€™s adjacency list)

Addition

Basic property of numbers: The sum of any three single-digit numbers is at most two digits long (holds for any base b â‰¥ 2).

This simple rule gives us a way to add two numbers in any base: align their right-hand ends, and then perform a single right-to-left pass in which the sum is computed digit by digit, maintaining the overflow as a carry. Since we know each individual sum is a two-digit number, the carry is always a single digit, and so at any given step, three single-digit numbers are added.

We will not spell out the pseudocode because we are so familiar with it. We will go ahead and anlyze its efficiency: We want the answer expressed as a function of the size of the input: the number of bits of x and y, the number of keystrokes needed to type them in.

Suppose x and y are each n bits long; in this chapter we will consistently use the letter nnnï»¿ for the sizes of numbers. Then the sum of xxxï»¿ and yyyï»¿ is n+1n + 1n+1ï»¿ bits at most, and each individual bit of this sum gets computed in a fixed amount of time. The total running time for the addition algorithm is therefore of the form c0+c1nc_0 + c_1nc0â€‹+c1â€‹nï»¿, where c0c_0c0â€‹ï»¿ and c1c_1c1â€‹ï»¿ are some constants; in other words, it is linear. Instead of worrying about the precise values of c0c_0c0â€‹ï»¿ and c1c_1c1â€‹ï»¿, we will focus on the big picture and denote the running time as O(n)O(n)O(n)ï»¿.

Some readers may be confused at this point: Why O(n)O(n)O(n)ï»¿ operations? Isnâ€™t binary addition something that computers today perform by just one instruction? There are two answers.

First, it is certainly true that in a single instruction we can add integers whose size in bits is within the word length of todayâ€™s computersâ€”32 perhaps. But, as will become apparent later in this chapter, it is often useful and necessary to handle numbers much larger than this, perhaps several thousand bits long. Adding and multiplying such large numbers on real computers is very much like performing the operations bit by bit. Second, when we want to understand algorithms, it makes sense to study even the basic algorithms that are encoded in the hardware of todayâ€™s computers. In doing so, we shall focus on the bit complexity of the algorithm, the number of elementary operations on individual bitsâ€”because this accounting reflects the amount of hardware, transistors and wires, necessary for implementing the algorithm.

Multiplication

algorithm for multiplying two numbers xxxï»¿ and yyyï»¿ is to create an array of intermediate sums, each representing the product of xxxï»¿ by a single digit of yyyï»¿. These values are appropriately left-shifted and then added up. Modular Arithmetic (DPV 1.2, unfinished)

Just like multiplication, division works on computers with limited bits.

Modular arithmetic is a system for dealing with restricted ranges of integers. We define xÂ moduloÂ Nx \text{ modulo } NxÂ moduloÂ Nï»¿ to be the remainder when xxxï»¿ is divided by NNNï»¿ ; that is, if x=qN+rx = qN + rx=qN+rï»¿ with 0â‰¤r<N0 \le r < N0â‰¤r<Nï»¿ , then xÂ moduloÂ Nx \text{ modulo } NxÂ moduloÂ Nï»¿ is equal to rrrï»¿. This gives an enhanced notion of equivalence between numbers: xxxï»¿ and yyyï»¿ are congruent modulo NNNï»¿ if they differ by a multiple of NNNï»¿ , or in symbols

Another interpretation is that modular arithmetic deals with all the integers, but divides them into NNNï»¿ equivalence classes, each of the form i+kN:kâˆˆZ{i + kN : k \in Z}i+kN:kâˆˆZï»¿ for some iiiï»¿ between 000ï»¿ and NNNï»¿

Universal Hash Functions

Family of hash functions that satisfy the following property:

For any two distinct data items xxxï»¿ and yyyï»¿, exactly âˆ£Hâˆ£/n|H|/nâˆ£Hâˆ£/nï»¿ of all the hash functions in HHHï»¿ map xxxï»¿ and yyyï»¿ to the same bucket, where nnnï»¿ is the number of buckets

In other words, for any two data items, the probability these items collide is 1/n if the hash function is randomly drawn from a universal family.

The divide-and-conquer step of the FFT can be drawn as a very simple circuit. Here is how a problem of size nnnï»¿ is reduced to two subproblems of size n/2n/2n/2ï»¿ (for clarity, one pair of outputs (j,j+n/2)(j, j + n/2)(j,j+n/2)ï»¿ is singled out):

the edges are wires carrying complex numbers from left to right. A weight of jjjï»¿ means â€œmultiply the number on this wire by Ï‰j\omega^jÏ‰jï»¿ .

  1. the inputs are arranged by increasing last bit of the binary representation of their index, resolving ties by looking at the next more significant bit(s).
    1. For n=8n=8n=8ï»¿, The resulting order in binary, 000, 100, 010, 110, 001, 101, 011, 111

    1. This path is most easily described using the binary representations of j and k (shown in Figure 10.4 for convenience). There are two edges out of each node, one going up (the 0-edge) and one going down (the 1-edge).
    1. To get to A(Ï‰k) from any input node, simply follow the edges specified in the bit representation of k, starting from the rightmost bit
  1. On the path between aja_jajâ€‹ï»¿ and A(Ï‰kA(\omega^kA(Ï‰kï»¿), the labels add up to jkmodâ€‰â€‰8jk \mod 8jkmod8ï»¿.

Good for modeling relationships like causalities, hierarchies, and temporal dependencies.

only edges (u,v)(u,v)(u,v)ï»¿ in a graph for which post(u)<post(v)post(u)< post(v)post(u)<post(v)ï»¿ are back edges â‡’ and dag cannot have back edges â‡’ In a DAG, every edge leads to a vertex with a lower postpostpostï»¿ number

So therefore

Also, since every DAG has at least one source and one sinkâ€¦We can do this linearization

  1. Find a source, output it, and delete it from graph
  1. Repeat until the graph is empty

Strongly Connected Components

Two nodes uuuï»¿ and vvvï»¿ of a directed graph are connected if there is a path from uuuï»¿ to vvvï»¿ and a path from vvvï»¿ to uuuï»¿.

Andâ€¦ turns out the meta-graph can be found in linear time by making further use of DFS.

Property 1: If the exploreexploreexploreï»¿ subroutine is started at node uuuï»¿, then it will terminate precisely when all nodes reachable from uuuï»¿ have been visited.

So if we call exploreexploreexploreï»¿ on a node that lies somewhere in a sinksinksinkï»¿ strongly connected component, then we will retrieve exactly that component.

Property 2: The node that receives the highest postpostpostï»¿ number in a DFS must lie in a source strongly connected component.
Property 3: If CCCï»¿ and Câ€™Câ€™Câ€™ï»¿ are strongly connected components, and there is an edge from a node in CCCï»¿ to a node in Câ€™Câ€™Câ€™ï»¿, then the highest postpostpostï»¿ number in CCCï»¿ is bigger than the highest postpostpostï»¿ number in Câ€™Câ€™Câ€™ï»¿.

Proof of property 3:

In proving Property 3, there are two cases to consider. If the depth-first search visits component CCCï»¿ before component Câ€™Câ€™Câ€™ï»¿, then clearly all of CCCï»¿ and Câ€²Câ€²Câ€²ï»¿ will be traversed before the procedure gets stuck (see Property 1). Therefore the first node visited in CCCï»¿ will have a higher post number than any node of Câ€²Câ€²Câ€²ï»¿. On the other hand, if Câ€²Câ€²Câ€²ï»¿ gets visited first, then the depth-first search will get stuck after seeing all of Câ€²Câ€²Câ€²ï»¿ but before seeing any of C, in which case the property follows immediately.

We can use the reverse graph GRG^{R}GRï»¿ and property 2 to find a node from the sinksinksinkï»¿ component of graph GGGï»¿

Once we have found the first strongly connected component and deleted it from the graph, the node with the highest post number among those remaining will belong to a sink strongly connected component of whatever remains of GGGï»¿. Therefore we can keep using the post numbering from our initial depth-first search on GRG^RGRï»¿ to successively output the second strongly connected component, the third strongly connected component, and so on. The resulting algorithm is this.

  1. Run DFS on GRG^RGRï»¿
  1. Run the undirected connected components algorithm on GGGï»¿, and during the DFS, process the vertices in decreasing order of their postpostpostï»¿ numbers from step 1.

This is linear time, only the constant is about twice of normal DFS search

Paths in Graphs: Distances (DPV 4.1)

The distance between two nodes is the length of the shortest path between them.

To get a concrete feel for this notion, consider a physical realization of a graph that has a ball for each vertex and a piece of string for each edge. If you lift the ball for vertex s high enough, the other balls that get pulled up along with it are precisely the vertices reachable from s. And to find their distances from s, you need only measure how far below s they hang.

Breadth-First Search (BFS) (DPV 4.2)

Initially the queue QQQï»¿ consists only of the root, sssï»¿, the one node at distance 000ï»¿. And for each subsequent distance d=1,2,3,â€¦d = 1, 2, 3, \dotsd=1,2,3,â€¦ï»¿, there is a point in time at which QQQï»¿ contains all the nodes at distance dddï»¿ and nothing else. As these nodes are processed (ejected off the front of the queue), their as-yet-unseen neighbors are injected into the end of the queue.

we can think of Dijkstraâ€™s algorithm as just BFS, except it uses a priority queue instead of a regular queue, so as to prioritize nodes in a way that takes edge lengths into account.

Priority Queue Implemention in Dijkstra (DPV 4.5)

Array

The simplest implementation of a priority queue is as an unordered array of key values for all potential elements (the vertices of the graph, in the case of Dijkstraâ€™s algorithm).

Initially, these values are set to âˆž\infinâˆžï»¿. An insert or decreasekey is fast, because it just involves adjusting a key value, an O(1)O(1)O(1)ï»¿ operation. To deletemindeletemindeleteminï»¿, on the other hand, requires a linear-time scan of the list.

Binary Heap

Elements are stored in a complete binary tree, in which each level is filled in from left to right, and must be full before the next level is started.

And special ordering constraint: the key value of any node of the tree is less than or equal to that of its children.

To insertinsertinsertï»¿, place the new element at the bottom of the tree (in the first available position), and let it â€œbubble up.â€ That is, if it is smaller than its parent, swap the two and repeat (Figure 4.11(b)â€“(d)). The number of swaps is at most the height of the tree, which is âŒŠlogâ¡2nâŒ‹\lfloor \log_2 n \rfloorâŒŠlog2â€‹nâŒ‹ï»¿ when there are nnnï»¿ elements.

A decreasekeydecreasekeydecreasekeyï»¿ is similar, except that the element is already in the tree, so we let it bubble up from its current position.

To deletemindeletemindeleteminï»¿, return the root value. To then remove this element from the heap, take the last node in the tree (in the rightmost position in the bottom row) and place it at the root. Let it â€œsift downâ€: if it is bigger than either child, swap it with the smaller child and repeat (Figure 4.11(e)â€“(g)). Again this takes O(log n) time.

The regularity of a complete binary tree makes it easy to represent using an array. The tree nodes have a natural ordering: row by row, starting at the root and moving left to right within each row. If there are n nodes, this ordering specifies their positions 1,2,â€¦,n1, 2, \dots , n1,2,â€¦,nï»¿ within the array. Moving up and down the tree is easily simulated on the array, using the fact that node number jjjï»¿ has parent âŒŠj/2âŒ‹\lfloor j/2 \rfloorâŒŠj/2âŒ‹ï»¿ and children 2j2j2jï»¿ and 2j+12j + 12j+1ï»¿

d-ary Heap

A d-ary heap is identical to a binary heap, except that nodes have d children instead of just two. This reduces the height of a tree with nnnï»¿ elements to Î˜(logâ¡dn)=Î˜((logâ¡n)/(logâ¡d))\Theta(\log_d n) = \Theta((\log n)/(\log d))Î˜(logdâ€‹n)=Î˜((logn)/(logd))ï»¿.

Inserts are therefore speeded up by a factor of Î˜(logd)\Theta(log d)Î˜(logd)ï»¿. DeleteminDeleteminDeleteminï»¿ operations, however, take a little longer, namely O(dlogâ¡dn)O(d \log_d n)O(dlogdâ€‹n)ï»¿

Detecting Negative Cycles (DPV 4.6.2)

In such situations, it doesnâ€™t make sense to even ask about shortest paths. There is a path of length 2 from A to E. But going round the cycle, thereâ€™s also a path of length 1, and going round multiple times, we find paths of lengths 0, âˆ’1, âˆ’2, and so on.

Fortunately, it is easy to automatically detect negative cycles and issue a warning. Such a cycle would allow us to endlessly apply rounds of update operations, reducing dist estimates every time.

Huffman Encoding O(nlogâ¡n)O(n \log n)O(nlogn)ï»¿

What is the most economic way of writing strings consisting of letters A,B,C,D?

The obvious choice is to use 222ï»¿ bits per symbolâ€”say codeword 000000ï»¿ for AAAï»¿, 010101ï»¿ for BBBï»¿, 101010ï»¿ for CCCï»¿, and 111111ï»¿ for DDDï»¿ - in which case 260260260ï»¿ megabits are needed in total. Can there possibly be a better encoding than this?

In search of inspiration, we take a closer look at our particular sequence and find that the four symbols are not equally abundant.

Is there some sort of variable-length encoding, in which just one bit is used for the frequently occurring symbol A, possibly at the expense of needing three or more bits for less common symbols?

A danger with having codewords of different lengths is that the resulting encoding may not be uniquely decipherable. For instance, if the codewords are {0,01,11,001}\{0, 01, 11, 001\}{0,01,11,001}ï»¿, the decoding of strings like 001001001ï»¿ is ambiguous. We will avoid this problem by insisting on the prefix-free property: no codeword can be a prefix of another codeword.

To measure how â€œgoodâ€ a coding tree is, we want a tree whose leaves each correspond to a symbol and minimizes the overall length of the encoding

Tells us that the two symbols with the smallest frequencies MUST be at the bottom of the optimal tree, as children of lowest internal node. â‡’ because otherwise swapping whatever node with either of those two would increase performance.

This suggests that we start constructing the tree greedily: find the two symbols with the smallest frequencies, say iiiï»¿ and jjjï»¿, and make them children of a new node, which then has frequency fi+fjf_i + f_jfiâ€‹+fjâ€‹ï»¿

There is another way to write this cost function that is very helpful. Although we are only given frequencies for the leaves, we can define the frequency of any internal node to be the sum of the frequencies of its descendant leaves; this is, after all, the number of times the internal node is visited during encoding or decoding. During the encoding process, each time we move down the tree, one bit gets output for every nonroot node through which we pass.

And therefore

The cost of a tree is the sum of the frequencies of all leaaves and internal nodes, except the root

Horn Formula

A framework for doing computer doing logical reasoning!

A literal is either: a variable or a variableâ€™s negation

Then we have two kinds of caluses:

  1. Implications, left hand side is and AND of any number of positive literals and right hand is a single positive iteral aâ€…â€ŠâŸ¹â€…â€Šba \implies baâŸ¹bï»¿
  1. Pure negative clauses, consisting of an OR of any number of negative literals (uË‰âˆ¨vË‰âˆ¨yË‰)(\bar{u} \vee \bar{v} \vee \bar{y})(uË‰âˆ¨vË‰âˆ¨yË‰â€‹)ï»¿

Given a set of clauses, the goal is to do satisfying assignment - determine whether there is a consistent explanation: an assignment of true/falsetrue / falsetrue/falseï»¿ values to the variables that satisfies all the clauses.

Our approach:

  1. Start with all variables falsefalsefalseï»¿
  1. and proceed to set some of them to truetruetrueï»¿
    1. one by one and only if we absolutely have to because an implication would be violated

Horn formulas lie at the heart of Prolog (â€œprogramming by logicâ€), a language in which you program by specifying desired properties of the output, using simple logical expressions

To see why the algorithm is correct, notice that if it returns an assignment, this assignment satisfies both the implications and the negative clauses, and so it is indeed a satisfying truth assignment of the input Horn formula. So we only have to convince ourselves that if the algorithm finds no satisfying assignment, then there really is none. This is so because our â€œstingyâ€ rule maintains the following invariant:

If a certain set of variables is set to true, then they must be true in any satisfying assignment.

Linear Programming and Reductions (DPV 7)

Linear Programming (DPV 7.1 + 7.4)

We are given a set of variables, and we want to assign real values to them so as to

  1. satisfy a set of linear equations / inequalities involving these variables
  1. maximize or minimize a given linear objective function

An inequality designates a half-space, the region on one side of the line.

Thus the set of all feasible solutions of this linear program, that is, the points (x1, x2) which satisfy all constraints, is the intersection of five half-spaces, and is a convex polygon.

We want to find the point in this polygon at which the objective functionâ€”the profitâ€”is maximized. The points with a profit of c dollars lie on the line x1+6x2=cx_1 + 6x_2 = cx1â€‹+6x2â€‹=cï»¿, which has a slope of âˆ’1/6âˆ’1/6âˆ’1/6ï»¿.

Since the goal is to maximize c, we must move the line as far up as possible, while still touching the feasible region. The optimum solution will be the very last feasible point that the profit line sees and must therefore be a vertex (or edge) of the polygon, as shown in the figure.

Standard Form of LP (DPV 7.1)

  1. All variables are nonnegative
  1. Constraints are all equations
  1. objective function is to be minimized

Duality of LP (DPV 7.4)

Duality theorem: If a linear program has a bounded optimum, then so does its dual, and the two optimum values coincide

Simplex Algorithm

Fact: each vertex is the unique point at which some subset of hyperplanes meet.

So to find a vertex:

  • Pick a subset of the inequalities. If there is a unique point that satisfies them with equality, and this point happens to be feasible, then it is a vertex.
    • Each vertex (of dimension n) is specified by a set of n inequalities.
    • Note that there might be vertices that are degenrate
      • They could be found by different subsets of inequalities
      • We just pretend they donâ€™t exist for now
  • Two vertices are neighbors if they have nâˆ’1n âˆ’ 1nâˆ’1ï»¿ defining inequalities in common.

Suppose we have a generic LP

For each iteration, we want to

  1. Check if the current vertex is optimal
  1. Determine where to move next

Note:

The origin is a vertex that we can start with.

  1. The current vertex(origin) is optimal iff âˆ€ciâ‰¤0\forall c_i \le 0âˆ€ciâ€‹â‰¤0ï»¿
  1. We can increase some xix_ixiâ€‹ï»¿ for which ci>0c_i > 0ciâ€‹>0ï»¿ (release the tight constraint xâ‰¥0x \ge 0xâ‰¥0ï»¿ â‡’ until we hit some other constraint (loose â‡’ tight)

Now we arrived at some other vertex uuuï»¿

Then we transform uuuï»¿ into the origin(shifting the coordinate system from the usual to the â€œlocalâ€ view of uuuï»¿)

These local coordinates consist of (appropriately scaled) distances y1,â€¦,yny_1, \dots , y_ny1â€‹,â€¦,ynâ€‹ï»¿ to the nnnï»¿ hyperplanes (inequalities) that define and enclose uuuï»¿:

  • aiâ‹…xâ‰¤bia_i \cdot x \le b_iaiâ€‹â‹…xâ‰¤biâ€‹ï»¿ â‡’ yi=biâˆ’aiâ‹…xy_i = b_i - a_i \cdot xyiâ€‹=biâ€‹âˆ’aiâ€‹â‹…xï»¿

The revised â€œlocalâ€ LP has the following three properties:

  1. It includes the inequalities yâ‰¥0y \ge 0yâ‰¥0ï»¿, which are simply the transformed versions of the inequalities defining uuuï»¿
  1. uuuï»¿ is the origin in y-space
  1. Cost function becomes maxâ¡cu+c~âŠ¤y\max c_u + \tilde{c}^\top ymaxcuâ€‹+c~âŠ¤yï»¿ where cuc_ucuâ€‹ï»¿ is the value of the objective function at uuuï»¿ and c~\tilde{c}c~ï»¿ is a transformed cost vector

The simplex function moves from vertex to neighboring vertex, stopping when the objective function is locally optimal, that is, when the coordinates of the local cost vector are all zero or negative.

Runtime Analysis

Suppose there are nnnï»¿ variables and mmmï»¿ inequalities

At each iteration:

  1. Each neighbors share nâˆ’1n-1nâˆ’1ï»¿ inequalities with the current vertex, at most nâ‹…mn \cdot mnâ‹…mï»¿ neighbors
    1. Choose which inequality to drop (nnnï»¿) and which new one to add (mmmï»¿)
  1. Naive way to perform each iteration
    1. Check each potential neighbor to see whether it really is a vertex of the polyhedron and to determine its cost
      1. Finding cost is just a dot product
      1. Checkingif it is a true vertex involves a solving a system of linear equations with nnnï»¿ equations in nnnï»¿ unknowns
        1. by Gaussian Elimination O(n3)O(n^3)O(n3)ï»¿
    1. âˆˆO(mn4)\in O(mn^4)âˆˆO(mn4)ï»¿ per iterations
  1. Not-naive way to perform each iteration
    1. Turns out that the per-iteration overhead of rewriting the LP in terms of the current local coordinates is just O((m+n)n)O((m + n)n)O((m+n)n)ï»¿
      1. exploits the fact that the local view changes only slightly between iterations, in just one of its defining inequalities
    1. To select the best neighbor
      1. we recall that the (local view of) the objective function is of the form maxâ¡cu+c~â‹…y\max c_u +\tilde{c} \cdot ymaxcuâ€‹+c~â‹…yï»¿ where cuc_ucuâ€‹ï»¿ is the value of the objective function at uuuï»¿.
      1. We pick any c~i>0\tilde{c}_i > 0c~iâ€‹>0ï»¿ (if there is none, then the current vertex is optimal and simplex halts)
    1. âˆˆO(mn)\in O(mn)âˆˆO(mn)ï»¿ per iteration
  1. At most (m+nn)m+n \choose n(nm+nâ€‹)ï»¿ iterations (vertices)
    1. Exponential in nnnï»¿
    1. In practice, such exponential examples do not occur

Finding a starting vertex for simplex

It turns out that finding a starting vertex can be reduced to an LP and solved by simplex!

Recall standard form:

  1. First make sure that RHS of equations are all non-negative
    1. If bi<0b_i < 0biâ€‹<0ï»¿, just multiply both sides of the iiiï»¿-th equation by âˆ’1-1âˆ’1ï»¿
    1. Create LP as follows
      1. Create artificial variables z1,â€¦,zmâ‰¥0z_1, \dots, z_m \ge 0z1â€‹,â€¦,zmâ€‹â‰¥0ï»¿, where mmmï»¿ is number of equations
      1. Add ziz_iziâ€‹ï»¿ to the LHS of the i-th equation
      1. Let the objective to be minimized be âˆ‘izi\sum_i z_iâˆ‘iâ€‹ziâ€‹ï»¿
    1. Itâ€™s easy to come up with a starting vertex
      1. âˆ€zi=bi\forall z_i = b_iâˆ€ziâ€‹=biâ€‹ï»¿ and other variables 0
    1. If the optimum value of z1+â‹¯+zmz_1 + \cdots + z_mz1â€‹+â‹¯+zmâ€‹ï»¿ is zero, then all ziz_iziâ€‹ï»¿â€™s obtained by simplex are zero, and hence from the optimum vertex of the new LP we get a starting feasible vertex of the original LP, just by ignoring the ziz_iziâ€‹ï»¿
    1. If âˆ‘izi\sum_i z_iâˆ‘iâ€‹ziâ€‹ï»¿ is not zero â‡’ the original linear program is infeasible

Degeneracy in Simplex Algorithm

When a vertex has more than nnnï»¿(dimension of variables) constraints intersecting, then choosing any one of sets of nnnï»¿ inequalties would give us the same solution

  • Causes simplex to return a suboptimal degenerate vertex simply because all its neighbors are identical to it.
  • One way to fix it is through a perturbation
    • Change each bib_ibiâ€‹ï»¿ by a tiny random amount to biÂ±Ïµib_i \pm \epsilon_ibiâ€‹Â±Ïµiâ€‹ï»¿
    • Doesnâ€™t change the essense of the LPLPLPï»¿ since Ïµ\epsilonÏµï»¿ are tiny, but has the effect of dirrentiating between the solutions of linear systems

Unboundedness of LP

  • In some cases an LP is unbounded, in that its objective function can be made arbitrarily large
  • simplex will discover it
    • in exploring the neighborhood of a vertex, it will notice that taking out an inequality and adding another leads to an underdetermined system of equations that has an infinity of solutions
    • The space of solutions contains a whole line across which the objective can become larger and larger, all the way to âˆž\infinâˆžï»¿

Network Flow (Maximum Flow âˆˆO(âˆ£Vâˆ£â‹…âˆ£Eâˆ£2)\in O(|V| \cdot |E|^2)âˆˆO(âˆ£Vâˆ£â‹…âˆ£Eâˆ£2)ï»¿) (DPV 7.2)

The networks we are dealing with consist of a directed graph G=(V,E)G = (V, E)G=(V,E)ï»¿; two special nodes s,tâˆˆVs, t \in Vs,tâˆˆVï»¿ , which are, respectively, a source and sink of G; and capacities ce>0c_e > 0ceâ€‹>0ï»¿ on the edges.

We would like to send as much things as possible from sssï»¿ to tttï»¿ without exceeding the capacities of any of the edges. A particular shipping scheme is called a flow and consists of a variable fef_efeâ€‹ï»¿ for each edge eeeï»¿ of the network, satisfying the following two properties:

  1. Doesnâ€™t violate edge capacities 0â‰¤feâ‰¤ce0 \le f_e \le c_e0â‰¤feâ€‹â‰¤ceâ€‹ï»¿
  1. For all nodes uuuï»¿ except sssï»¿ and tttï»¿, the amount of flow entering and the amount of flow leaving uuuï»¿ should be the same â‡’ flow is conserved
    1. âˆ‘(w,u)âˆˆEfwu=âˆ‘(u,z)âˆˆEfuz\sum_{(w,u) \in E} f_{wu} = \sum_{(u,z) \in E} f_{uz}âˆ‘(w,u)âˆˆEâ€‹fwuâ€‹=âˆ‘(u,z)âˆˆEâ€‹fuzâ€‹ï»¿

The size of a flow is the total quantity sent form sssï»¿ to tttï»¿ and is the quantity leaving sssï»¿

We can solve max flow by Ford-Fulkerson

  1. Find an augmenting path in the graph
    1. BFS(Edmondsâ€“Karp), A* search, RL Model
  1. Construct the residual graph by augmenting the path based on the original graph and augmenting path
  1. Do this until no augmenting path can be found.

The max flow problem can also be reduced to a LP problem

Once we have studied the simplex algorithm in more detail (DPV 7.6), we will be in a position to understand exactly how it handles flow LPs, which is useful as a source of inspiration for designing direct max-flow algorithms. It turns out that in fact the behavior of simplex has an elementary interpretation:

  • Start with zero flow.
  • Repeat: choose an appropriate path from s to t, and increase flow along the edges of this path as much as possible.
  • See Figure 7.5 (a-d) for example
  • There is just one complication.
    • What if we had initially chosen a different path, the one in Figure 7.5(e)?
      • This gives only one unit of flow and yet seems to block all other paths.
    • Simplex gets around this problem by also allowing paths to cancel existing flow.
    • In this particular case, it would subsequently choose the path of Figure 7.5(f). Edge (b,a)(b, a)(b,a)ï»¿ of this path isnâ€™t in the original network and has the effect of canceling flow previously assigned to edge (a,b)(a, b)(a,b)ï»¿.

in each iteration simplex looks for an sâ†’ts \rightarrow tsâ†’tï»¿ path whose edges (u,v)(u, v)(u,v)ï»¿ can be of two types

  1. (u,v)(u,v)(u,v)ï»¿ is in the original network, and is not yet at full capacity
  1. The reverse edge (v,u)(v,u)(v,u)ï»¿ is in the original network, and there is some flow along it

If the current flow is f , then in the first case, edge (u,v)(u, v)(u,v)ï»¿ can handle up to cuvâˆ’fuvc_{uv} âˆ’ f_{uv}cuvâ€‹âˆ’fuvâ€‹ï»¿ additional units of flow, and in the second case, upto fvu additional units (canceling all or part of the existing flow on (v,u)(v, u)(v,u)ï»¿). These flow-increasing opportunities can be captured in a residual network Gf=(V,Ef)G^f = (V, E^f)Gf=(V,Ef)ï»¿, which has exactly the two types of edges listed, with residual capacities cfc^fcfï»¿:

Thus we can equivalently think of simplex as choosing an sâˆ’ts âˆ’ tsâˆ’tï»¿ path in the residual network

Partition the nodes of the oil network (Figure 7.4) into two groups, L={s,a,b}L = \{s, a, b\}L={s,a,b}ï»¿ and R={c,d,e,t}R = \{c, d, e, t\}R={c,d,e,t}ï»¿:

Any oil transmitted must pass from LLLï»¿ to RRRï»¿. Therefore, no flow can possibly exceed the total capacity of the edges from LLLï»¿ to RRRï»¿, which is 7. But this means that the flow we found earlier, of size 7, must be optimal

Some cuts are large and give loose upper boundsâ€” cut({s,b,c},{a,d,e,t})cut(\{s, b, c\}, \{a, d, e, t\})cut({s,b,c},{a,d,e,t})ï»¿ has a capacity of 19. But there is also a cut of capacity 7, which is effectively a certificate of optimality of the maximum flow. Such a cut always exists.

Max-flow min-cut theorem

The size of the maximum flow in a network equals the capacity of the smallest (s,t)(s, t)(s,t)ï»¿-cut. Moreover, our algorithm automatically finds this cut as a by-product!

Bipartite Matching

There is an edge between a boy and girl if they like each other (for instance, Al likes all the girls). Is it possible to choose couples so that everyone has exactly one partner, and it is someone they like? In graph-theoretic jargon, is there a perfect matching?

Create a new source node, s, with outgoing edges to all the boys; a new sink node, t, with incoming edges from all the girls; and direct all the edges in the original bipartite graph from boy to girl (Figure 7.8). Finally, give every edge a capacity of 1. Then there is a perfect matching if and only if this network has a flow whose size equals the number of couples.

Nice property about max flow problem: if all edge capacities are integers, then the optimal flow found by our algorithm is integral

Circuit Evaluation (DPV 7.7)

We are given a Boolean circuit, a DAG of gates of the following types

  • Input gates have indegree zero, with value true or false
  • AND gates and OR gates have indegree 2
  • NOT gates have indegree 1

Additionally, one of the gates is designated as the output.

CIRCUIT VALUE problem: apply Boolean logic to the gates in topological order, does the output evaluate to true?

â¬†ï¸Additional Constraints imposed by different gates

Those constraints forces each xgx_gxgâ€‹ï»¿ to be 000ï»¿(false) or 111ï»¿(true).

Turns out the CIRCUIT VALUE problem is the most general problem solvable in polynomial time, every algorithm will eventually run on a computer, and the computer is ultimately a Boolean combinational circuit implemented on a chip. If the algorithm runs in polynomial time, it can be rendered as a Boolean circuit consisting of polynomially many copies of the computerâ€™s circuit, one per unit of time.

Hence, the fact that CIRCUIT VALUE reduces to linear programming means that all problems that can be solved in polynomial time do!

NP-Complete Problems (DPV 8)

Search Problems (DPV8.1)

A search problem is specified by an algorithm CCCï»¿ that takes two inputs, an instance IIIï»¿ and a proposed solution SSSï»¿, and runs in time polynomial in âˆ£Iâˆ£|I|âˆ£Iâˆ£ï»¿. We say SSSï»¿ is a solution to IIIï»¿ if and only if C(I,S)=trueC(I,S) = \text{true}C(I,S)=trueï»¿.

SAT(Satisfiability) problem

Given a Boolean Formula in Conjunctive Normal Form (CNF), which is a collection of clauses each containing of disjunction of several literals(either a Boolean variable or the negation of one), find a satisfying truth assignment.

Horn Formula:

  • Special form of SAT problem
  • At most one positive literal
  • Greedy algorithm (DPV 5.3)

2-literals case:

  • Solved by DPV 3.28 by strongly connected components of a particularly constructed graph
  • Or another polynomial algorithm (DPV 9)

Traveling salesman problem (TSP)

Given nnnï»¿ vertices 1,â€¦,n1, \dots, n1,â€¦,nï»¿ and all n(nâˆ’1)/2n(n-1)/2n(nâˆ’1)/2ï»¿ distances between them, as well as budget bbbï»¿. We want to find a tour, a cycle that passes through every vertex exactly once, of total cost bbbï»¿ or less (or report that no such tour exists)

In other words (in search problemâ€™s perspective), we want to find a permutation Ï„(1),â€¦,Ï„(n)\tau(1), \dots, \tau(n)Ï„(1),â€¦,Ï„(n)ï»¿ such that when they are toured in this order, the total distance covered is at most bbbï»¿:

Thereâ€™s a budget â‡’ solution to a search problem should be easy to recognize (polynomial checkable).

Euler and Rudrata

Eulerâ€™s Bridge problem: Is there a path that visits each edge exactly once?

Or in other words: When can a graph be drawn without lifting the pencil from the paper?

Rudrataâ€™s Cycle problem: Can one visit all the squares of the chessboard, without repeating any square, in one long walk that ends at the starting square and at each step makes a legal knight move?

In other words: Given a graph, find a cycle that visits each vertex exactly once - or report that no such cycle exists â‡’ Oops! Looks similar to TSP!

Cuts and Bisections

Balanced Cut problem: Given a graph with nnnï»¿ vertices and a budget bbbï»¿, partition the vertices into two sets SSSï»¿ and TTTï»¿ such that âˆ£Sâˆ£,âˆ£Tâˆ£â‰¥n/3|S|, |T| \ge n/3âˆ£Sâˆ£,âˆ£Tâˆ£â‰¥n/3ï»¿ and such that there are at most bbbï»¿ edges between SSSï»¿ and TTTï»¿

Applications: Clustering (problem of segmenting an image into its constituent components (say, an elephant standing in a grassy with a clear blue sky above) â‡’ Put a node for each pixel and put an edge between nodes whose corresponding pixels are spatially close together and also similar in color.

Three-Dimensional Matching

nnnï»¿ boys, nnnï»¿ girls and nnnï»¿ pets, and the compatibilities among them are specified by a set of triples {b,g,p}\{ b, g, p \}{b,g,p}ï»¿, each containing a boy, a girl, and a pet. We want to find nnnï»¿ disjoint triples and thereby create nnnï»¿ harmonious households

Independent set, vertex cover, and clique

Independent Set Problem: Given a graph and an integer gggï»¿, find gggï»¿ vertices that are independent (no two of which have an edge between them)

Vertex Cover (Special Case of Set Cover): input is a graph and a budget bbbï»¿, find bbbï»¿ vertices that cover every edge

Set Cover: Given a set EEEï»¿ and several subsets of it, S1,â€¦,SmS_1, \dots, S_mS1â€‹,â€¦,Smâ€‹ï»¿, along with a budget bbbï»¿. Select bbbï»¿ of subsets so that their union is EEEï»¿.

CLIQUE problem: Given a graph and a goal gggï»¿ï¼Œ find a set of gggï»¿ vertices such that all possible edges between them are present.

Longest Path: Given a graph GGGï»¿ with nonnegative edge weights ad two distinguished vertices sssï»¿ and tttï»¿, along with a goal gggï»¿, we want to find a path from sssï»¿ to tttï»¿ with total weight at least gggï»¿.

Knapsack and subset sum

P and NP

Search Problems: There is an efficient checking algorithm CCCï»¿ that takes input a given input IIIï»¿ (data specifying the problem) and a potential solution SSSï»¿, and outputs truetruetrueï»¿ iff SSSï»¿ is a solution to instance IIIï»¿ in polynomial time âˆ£Iâˆ£|I|âˆ£Iâˆ£ï»¿.

We denote the class of all search problems by NPNPNPï»¿ (nondeterministic polynomial time).

We also denote the class of all search problems that can be solved in polynomial time by PâŠ†NPP \sube NPPâŠ†NPï»¿

if P=NPP = NPP=NPï»¿, thereâ€™s an efficient method to prove any mathematical statement, thus eliminating the need for mathematicians! â‡’ this is a nice intuition of why Pâ‰ NPP \ne NPPî€ =NPï»¿, however proving this is extremely difficult.

Reductions in search problems

The problem on the left side of the table are all in some sense - exactly the same problem, except that they are stated in different languages. We will use reductions to show that those problems are the hardest problems in NPNPNPï»¿ - if even one of them has a polynomial time algorithm, then every problem in NPNPNPï»¿ has a polynomial time algorithm.

A reduction from search problem AAAï»¿ to search problem BBBï»¿ is a polynomial-time algorithm fffï»¿ that transforms any instance IIIï»¿ of AAAï»¿ into an instance f(I)f(I)f(I)ï»¿ of BBBï»¿, together with another polynomial-time algorithm hhhï»¿ that maps any solution SSSï»¿ of f(I)f(I)f(I)ï»¿ back into a solution h(S)h(S)h(S)ï»¿ of IIIï»¿. If f(I)f(I)f(I)ï»¿ has no solution, then neither does IIIï»¿.

Now letâ€™s define the class of hardest search problems

A search problem is NP-complete if all other search problems reduce to it.

Nice properties about reduction:

  • Composability
    • If Aâ†’Bâˆ§Bâ†’CA \rightarrow B \wedge B \rightarrow CAâ†’Bâˆ§Bâ†’Cï»¿, then Aâ†’CA \rightarrow CAâ†’Cï»¿
    • If we proved that AAAï»¿ is NP-Complete, we just need to show Aâ†’BA \rightarrow BAâ†’Bï»¿ to show that BBBï»¿ is NP-Complete, because now all problems in NP reduce to BBBï»¿.
  • If Aâ†’BA \rightarrow BAâ†’Bï»¿, then
    • difficulty flows in the direction of the arrow
    • efficient algorithms move in the other direction

A side note on factoring:

Factoring is the task of finding all prime factors of a given integer, but the difficulty of factoring is of a different nature and nobody believes that factoring is NP-complete. One major difference is thereâ€™s no scenario such that no solution exists, and the problem succumbs to the power of quantum computation.

Coping with NP-Completeness (DPV 9)

If we have a hard problem

  1. Start by proving that it is NP-Complete
    1. A proof by generalization
    1. Simple reduction from another NP-Complete problem to this problem
  1. Once problem is proved NP-Complete
    1. Special cases of the problem might be solved in linear time
    1. Graph problems can be solved by DP in linear time
    1. approximation algorithm
      1. falls short of the optimum but never by too much
      1. Greedy algorithm for set cover O(logâ¡n)O(\log n)O(logn)ï»¿
    1. heuristics
      1. algorithms with no guarantees on either the running time or the degree of approximation
      1. rely on ingenuity, intuition, a good understanding of the application, meticulous experimentation to tackle the problem

Intelligent Exaustive Search (DPV 9.1)

Backtracking

It is often possible to reject a solution by looking at just a small portion of it

By quickly checking and discrediting some partial assignment, we are able to prune some portion of the search space.

Consider the Boolean formula Ï•(w,x,y,z)\phi(w,x,y,z)Ï•(w,x,y,z)ï»¿ specified by the set of clauses

We will start by branching on any one variable (wwwï»¿)

No clause is immediately violated, thus neither of those partial assignments can be eliminated outright. Letâ€™s keep branching on xxxï»¿ with w=0w=0w=0ï»¿

Now we see that w=0,x=1w=0, x=1w=0,x=1ï»¿ violates (wâˆ¨xË‰)(w \vee \bar{x})(wâˆ¨xË‰)ï»¿ and this helps us prune a good chunk of search space.

In the case of Boolean satisfiability, each node of the search tree can be described either by a partial assignment or by the clauses that remain when those values are plugged into the original formula.

For instance, if w=0w = 0w=0ï»¿ and x=0x = 0x=0ï»¿ then any clause with wwwï»¿ or xxxï»¿ is instantly satisfied and any literal wwwï»¿ or xxxï»¿ is not satisfied and can be removed. Whatâ€™s left is

Likewise for w=0,x=1w=0, x=1w=0,x=1ï»¿

â€œempty clauseâ€ rules out satisfiability.

Thus the nodes of the search tree, representing partial assignments, are themselves SAT sub-problems. This alternative representation is helpful for making the two decisions that repeatedly arise: which subproblem to expand next, and which branching variable to use.

Since the benefit of backtracking lies in its ability to eliminate portions of the search space, and since this happens only when an empty clause is encountered, it makes sense to choose the subproblem that contains the smallest clause and to then branch on a variable in that clause.

More abstractly, a backtracking algorithm requires a test that looks like a subproblem and quickly declares one of three outcomes

  1. Failure: the subproblem has no solution
  1. Success: A solution to the subproblem is found
  1. Uncertainty

In the case of SAT, this test declares failure if there is an empty clause, success if there are no clauses, and uncertainty otherwise.

Branch-and-bound

Same principle of backtracing algorithm can be generalized from search problem to optimization problems.

Suppose we have a minimization problem

As before, we need a basis for eliminating partial solutions, since there is no other source of efficiency in our method. To reject a subproblem, we must be certain that its cost exceeds that of some other solution we have already encountered. But its exact cost is unknown to us and is generally not efficiently computable. So instead we use a quick lower bound on this cost.

Use this on TSP problem with graph G=(V,E)G = (V,E)G=(V,E)ï»¿ with edge lengths de>0d_e > 0deâ€‹>0ï»¿:

  • A partial solution is a simple path aâ‡ba \rightsquigarrow baâ‡bï»¿ passing through some vertices SâŠ†VS \sube VSâŠ†Vï»¿, where SSSï»¿ includes the endpoints aaaï»¿ and bbbï»¿.
    • We can denote such a partial solution by [a,S,b][a,S,b][a,S,b]ï»¿ where aaaï»¿ is fixed throughout the algorithm
    • Corresponding subproblem is to find the best completion of the tour (cheapest complementary path bâ‡ab \rightsquigarrow abâ‡aï»¿ with intermediate nodes Vâˆ’SV - SVâˆ’Sï»¿)
  • Initial problem is [a,{a},a][a, \{a\}, a][a,{a},a]ï»¿
  • At each step we extend a particular partial solution [a,S,b][a,S,b][a,S,b]ï»¿ by a single edge (b,x)(b,x)(b,x)ï»¿, where xâˆˆVâˆ’Sx \in V-SxâˆˆVâˆ’Sï»¿
    • up to âˆ£Vâˆ’Sâˆ£|V-S|âˆ£Vâˆ’Sâˆ£ï»¿ ways to do this
    • leads to a subproblem of [a,Sâˆª{x},x][a, S \cup \{x\}, x][a,Sâˆª{x},x]ï»¿
  • To impose a lower-bound on completing a partial tour [a,S,b][a,S,b][a,S,b]ï»¿, many methods have been proposed, but we can look at some easy ideas:
    • Remaining vertices are Vâˆ’SV-SVâˆ’Sï»¿, plus edges from aaaï»¿ and bbbï»¿ to Vâˆ’SV-SVâˆ’Sï»¿, therefore its cost is at least the sum of
      • Lightest edge from aaaï»¿ to Vâˆ’SV-SVâˆ’Sï»¿
      • Lightest edge from bbbï»¿ to Vâˆ’SV-SVâˆ’Sï»¿
      • Minimum Spanning Tree of Vâˆ’SV-SVâˆ’Sï»¿

Approximation Algorithms (DPV 9.2)

Suppose we have an algorithm AAAï»¿ for our problem which given the instance IIIï»¿ returns a solution with value A(I)A(I)A(I)ï»¿, the approximation ratio of algorithm AAAï»¿ is defined as

Î±A\alpha_AÎ±Aâ€‹ï»¿ measures by the factor by which the output of algorithm AAAï»¿ exceeds the optimal solution, on the worst-case input.

When faced with an NP-complete optimization problem, a reasonable goal is to look for an approximation algorithm AAAï»¿ whose Î±A\alpha_AÎ±Aâ€‹ï»¿ is as small as possible.

Vertex Cover

Given an undirected graph G=(V,E)G = (V,E)G=(V,E)ï»¿, find a subset of the vertices SâŠ†VS \sube VSâŠ†Vï»¿ that touches every edge and âˆ£Sâˆ£|S|âˆ£Sâˆ£ï»¿ is minimized.
  • A special case of SET COVER
  • From DPV 5.4, we know it can be approximated with a factor of O(logâ¡n)O(\log n)O(logn)ï»¿ by greedy

Matching: A subset of edges have no vertices in common are matched together. A matching is maximal if no more edges can be added to it.

any vertex cover of a graph GGGï»¿ must be at least as large as the number of edges in any matching in GGGï»¿; that is, any matching provides a lower bound on OPT. Simply because each edge of the matching must be covered by one of its endpoints in any vertex cover

let SSSï»¿ be a set that contains both endpoints of each edge in a maximal matching MMMï»¿ . Then SSSï»¿ must be a vertex coverâ€”if it isnâ€™t, that is, if it doesnâ€™t touch some edge eâˆˆEe \in EeâˆˆEï»¿, then MMMï»¿ could not possibly be maximal since we could still add eeeï»¿ to it. But our cover SSSï»¿ has 2âˆ£Mâˆ£2|M|2âˆ£Mâˆ£ï»¿ vertices. And from the previous paragraph we know that any vertex cover must have size at least âˆ£Mâˆ£|M|âˆ£Mâˆ£ï»¿, so we are done (SSSï»¿ is our approximation of vertex cover)!

This simple procedure always returns a vertex cover whose size is at most twice optimal!

Clustering

We have some data thaty we want to divide into groups â‡’ first define the notion of â€œdistanceâ€, which has to satisfy the usual â€œmetricâ€ properties

  1. d(x,y)â‰¥0d(x,y) \ge 0d(x,y)â‰¥0ï»¿ for all x,yx,yx,yï»¿
  1. d(x,y)=0d(x,y) = 0d(x,y)=0ï»¿ iff x=yx=yx=yï»¿

    1. Triangle inequality

The problem is NP-hard, but thereâ€™s an approximation algorithm:

  • Pick kkkï»¿ of data points as cluster centers, assign each of the reamining points to the center closest to it, creating kkkï»¿ clusters
    • Centers picked one at a time, rule: always pick the next center to be as far as possible from the centers chosen so far

Let xâˆˆXx \in XxâˆˆXï»¿ be the point farthest from Î¼1,â€¦,Î¼k\mu_1, \dots , \mu_kÎ¼1â€‹,â€¦,Î¼kâ€‹ï»¿ (in other words the next center we would have chosen, if we wanted k+1k+1k+1ï»¿ of them), and let rrrï»¿ be its distance to its closest center. Then every point in XXXï»¿ must be within distance rrrï»¿ of its cluster center. By triangular inequality, this means every cluster has diameter at most 2r2r2rï»¿.

we have identified k+1k + 1k+1ï»¿ points {Î¼1,Î¼2,â€¦,Î¼k,x}\{\mu_1, \mu_2, \dots , \mu_k, x\}{Î¼1â€‹,Î¼2â€‹,â€¦,Î¼kâ€‹,x}ï»¿ that are all at a distance at least rrrï»¿ from each other â‡’ Any partition into kkkï»¿ clusters must put two of these points in the same cluster and must therefore have diameter at least rrrï»¿.

TSP

We saw that the triangle inequality helped making the k-CLUSTER problem approximable; In TRAVELLING SALESMAN PROBLEM, if the distances between cities satisfy the metric properties, then there is an algorithm that outputs a tour of length at most 1.51.51.5ï»¿ times optimal. We will look at a weaker result that achieves a factor of 222ï»¿.

Is there a structure that is easy to compute and plausibly related to the best traveling salesman tour? Turns out to be the minimum spanning tree.

Removing any edge from a traveling salesman tour leaves a path through all the vertices, with is a spanning tree, therefore

Now a MST is not necessarily a tour. In order to make this a tour, try use each edge twice, then follow the shape of the MST we end up with a tour that visits all the cities, some of them more than once.

Therefore this tour has a length at most twice the MST cost

To fix the problem of visiting some cities more than once, the tour should simply skip any city it is about to revisit, and instead move directly to the next new city in its list (By the triangle inequality, these bypasses can only make the overall tour shorter).

General TSP

Much harder to approximate if TSP does not satisfy the triangle inequality!

Recall that we have a polynomial-time reduction from TSP I(G,C)I(G,C)I(G,C)ï»¿ instance:

  • If GGGï»¿ has a Rudrata path, then OPT(I(G,C))=nOPT(I(G,C)) = nOPT(I(G,C))=nï»¿, the number of vertices in GGGï»¿.
  • If GGGï»¿ has no Rudrata path, then OPT(I(G,C))â‰¥n+COPT(I(G,C)) \ge n+COPT(I(G,C))â‰¥n+Cï»¿

This means even an approximate solution to TSP would enable us to solve RUDRATA PATH!

So unless P=NPP = NPP=NPï»¿, there cannot exist an efficient approximation algorithm for the general TSP.

Knapsack

This approximation: Given any Ïµ>0\epsilon > 0Ïµ>0ï»¿, it will return a solution of value at least (1âˆ’Ïµ)(1-\epsilon)(1âˆ’Ïµ)ï»¿ times the optimal value, in time it only scales polynomially in input size and in 1/Ïµ1/\epsilon1/Ïµï»¿.

The approximability hierarchy

NP-Complete optimization problems are classified as follows (assuming Pâ‰ NPP \ne NPPî€ =NPï»¿, if P=NPP = NPP=NPï»¿ then all classes collapse into one):

  • Those of which like TSP, no finite approximation ratio is possible
  • Those for which an approximation ratio is possible, but there are limits to how small this can be
    • Vertex Cover, k-Cluster, TSP with triangle inequality
  • Those for which approximability has no limits, and polynomial approximation algorithms with error ratios arbitrarily close to zero exist.
    • Knapsack
  • Those for which the approximation ratio is about logâ¡n\log nlognï»¿
    • Set Cover

Local Search Heuristics (DPV 9.3)

For minimization problem, â€œtry outâ€ local solutions, keep them if they work well

On each iteration, the current solution is replaced by a better one close to it, in its neighborhood. This neighborhood structure is something we impose upon the problem and is the central design decision in local search.

TSP with local search

Assume we have all interpoint distances between nnnï»¿ cities, giving a search space of (nâˆ’1)!(n âˆ’ 1)!(nâˆ’1)!ï»¿ different tours. What is a good notion of neighborhood?

  • Define two tours as being close if they only differ in a few edges
    • They cannot differ in just one edge (cuz we have to include every vertices)
    • So we will consider differences of two edges
    • We define the 2-change neighborhood of tour s as being the set of tours that can be obtained by removing two edges of s and then putting in two other edges.
  • It is quick because a tour only has O(n2)O(n^2)O(n2)ï»¿ neighbours
    • But unclear how many iterations will be needed
  • But the final answer is only lcocally optimal
    • We can fix by making it a 3-change, or 4-change, etc. But each iteration is more expensive now

Graph Partitioning

Removing the restriction on the sizes of AAAï»¿ and BBBï»¿ would give the MINIMUM CUT problem, which can be efficiently solved using flow techniques.

However, this present variant is NP-hard.

Let (A,B)(A,B)(A,B)ï»¿ with âˆ£Aâˆ£=âˆ£Bâˆ£|A| = |B|âˆ£Aâˆ£=âˆ£Bâˆ£ï»¿ be a candidate solution; We will define its neighbors to be all solutions obtainable by swapping one pair of vertices across the cut: all solutions of the form (Aâˆ’{a}+{b},Bâˆ’{b}+{a})(A - \{a\} + \{b\}, B - \{b\} + \{a\})(Aâˆ’{a}+{b},Bâˆ’{b}+{a})ï»¿ where aâˆˆA,bâˆˆBa \in A, b \in BaâˆˆA,bâˆˆBï»¿.

How do we improve local search procedures?

Dealing with Local Optima

Randomization and restarts

Randomization

  • Invaluable ally in local search
  • Used to
    • pick a random initial solution
    • choose a local move when several are available

When there are many local optima, randomization is a way of making sure that there is at least some probability of getting to the right one.

Simulated Annealing

As the problem size grows, the ratio of bad to good local optima often increases, sometimes to the point of being exponentially large. In such cases, simply repeating the local search a few times is ineffective.

  • What about we occasionally allow moves that actually increase the cost, in the hope that they will pull the search out of dead ends?
  • The method of simulated annealing redefines the local search by introducing the notion of a temperature TTTï»¿ .
  • Trick is to start with TTTï»¿ large and gradually reduce it to zero
  • it is quite an art to choose a good timetable by which to decrease the temperature, called an annealing schedule.

Randomized Algorithms

We now study randomized algorithms instead of a deterministic algorithm. A randomized algorithm AAAï»¿ can be seen as a regular algorithm but takes two inputs: usual input xxxï»¿ and uniformly random string râˆˆ{0,1}Rr \in \{0,1\}^Rrâˆˆ{0,1}Rï»¿ for some RRRï»¿. We generally categorize randomized algorithms into two classes

  • Las Vegas
    • Algorithms for which correctness guarentees
    • Runtime t(x,r)t(x,r)t(x,r)ï»¿ with input xxxï»¿ with randomness rrrï»¿ is a random variable
    • Then we talk about T(n)T(n)T(n)ï»¿ being the expected runtime of AAAï»¿ on inputs xxxï»¿ of size nnnï»¿
      • T(n)=maxâ¡âˆ£xâˆ£=nErt(x,r)T(n) = \max_{|x| = n} \mathbb{E}_{r} t(x,r)T(n)=maxâˆ£xâˆ£=nâ€‹Erâ€‹t(x,r)ï»¿
    • e.g. Quicksort worst case is O(n2)O(n^2)O(n2)ï»¿ but expectation is O(nlogâ¡n)O(n \log n)O(nlogn)ï»¿
  • Monte Carlo
    • Runtime is always bounded by some desired bound
    • but correctness is a random variable
    • Let Î”(x,r)\Delta(x,r)Î”(x,r)ï»¿ be the â€œindicator random variableâ€ for the event that A(x,r)A(x,r)A(x,r)ï»¿ returns an incorrect value (Î”(x,r)=1\Delta(x,r) = 1Î”(x,r)=1ï»¿ when A(x,r)A(x,r)A(x,r)ï»¿ is incorrect and Î”(x,r)=0\Delta (x,r) = 0Î”(x,r)=0ï»¿ otherwise.
    • EÎ”(x,r)=P(Î”(x,r)=1)=Î´>0\mathbb{E} \Delta(x,r) = \mathbb{P}(\Delta (x,r) = 1) = \delta >0EÎ”(x,r)=P(Î”(x,r)=1)=Î´>0ï»¿

Generating Random Primes

  • Pick a random n-bit number NNNï»¿
  • Run a primality test on NNNï»¿
  • If it passes the test, output NNNï»¿, otherwise repeat the process

Chamichael numbers

The smallest Carmichael number is 561=3â‹…11â‹…17561 = 3 \cdot 11 \cdot 17561=3â‹…11â‹…17ï»¿, it is not a prime; Yet it fools the fermat test because a560â‰¡1modâ€‰â€‰561a^{560} \equiv 1 \mod 561a560â‰¡1mod561ï»¿ for all values of aaaï»¿ relatively prime to 561561561ï»¿. For a long time it was thought that there might be only finitely many numbers of this type, but we know that they are infinite, but exceedingly rare.

There is a way around Carmichael numbers, using a slightly more refined primality test due to Rabin and Miller.

Write Nâˆ’1N-1Nâˆ’1ï»¿ in the form 2tu2^t u2tuï»¿, we will choose a random base aaaï»¿ and check the value of aNâˆ’1modâ€‰â€‰Na^{N-1} \mod NaNâˆ’1modNï»¿. Perform this computation by first determining aumodâ€‰â€‰Na^u \mod NaumodNï»¿ and then repeatedly squaring, to get the sequence:

If aNâˆ’1â‰¡Ì¸1modâ€‰â€‰Na^{N-1} \not\equiv 1 \mod NaNâˆ’1î€ â‰¡1modNï»¿, then NNNï»¿ is composite by Fermatâ€™s little theorem, and weâ€™re done. If aNâˆ’1â‰¡1modâ€‰â€‰Na^{N-1} \equiv 1 \mod NaNâˆ’1â‰¡1modNï»¿, we conduct a little follow-up test

  • Somewhere in the preceeding sequence, we ran into a 1 for the first time.
    • If this happened after the first position (if aumodâ€‰â€‰Nâ‰ 1a^u \mod N \ne 1aumodNî€ =1ï»¿) and the preceeding value in the value in the list is not âˆ’1modâ€‰â€‰N-1 \mod Nâˆ’1modNï»¿, then we declare NNNï»¿ composite
    • we have found a nontrivial square root of 1 modulo N : a number that is not Â±1 mod N but that when squared is equal to 1 mod N
      • Such a number can only exist if NNNï»¿ is composite

Quicksort

The key insight is that the runtime t(A,r)t(A, r)t(A,r)ï»¿ is, up to a constant factor, equal to the number of comparisons performed by QuickSort.

This is because for every recursive call on some array of size, say, lllï»¿, the total time spent at that level of recursion (steps 1 through 3 above) is Î˜(l)\Theta(l)Î˜(l)ï»¿, whereas the number of comparisons is also lâˆ’1=Î˜(l)l âˆ’ 1 = \Theta(l)lâˆ’1=Î˜(l)ï»¿.

Furthermore, for any pair of indices iâ‰ jâˆˆ{1,â€¦,n}i \ne j \in \{1, \dots , n\}iî€ =jâˆˆ{1,â€¦,n}ï»¿, A[i]A[i]A[i]ï»¿ is compared to A[j]A[j]A[j]ï»¿ either 000ï»¿ or 111ï»¿ times throughout the entire run of the algorithm; this is because for two items to be compared, one of them had to have been the pivot, in which case the non-pivot item is then put into either L or R and never has a chance to be compared with the pivot again.

Thus if we define an indicator random variable Xi,jX_{i,j}Xi,jâ€‹ï»¿ which is 111ï»¿ if the i-th smallest element is ever compared with the j-th smallest and 000ï»¿ otherwise, we have that

where CCCï»¿ is a constant

Applying linearity of expectation,

Letâ€™s try to bound ErXi,j\mathbb{E}_r X_{i,j}Erâ€‹Xi,jâ€‹ï»¿

What is the probability that the ith and jth smallest elements (call them ai,aja_i, a_jaiâ€‹,ajâ€‹ï»¿) are ever compared? If we trace the QuickSort recursion tree from the root, both elements start off being in the same recursive subproblem, then when the root recursion node picks a random pivot, if that pivot is either <ai< a_i<aiâ€‹ï»¿ or >aj> a_j>ajâ€‹ï»¿ then aia_iaiâ€‹ï»¿ and aja_jajâ€‹ï»¿ either both go to LLLï»¿ or both go to RRRï»¿ (i.e. stay in the same recursive subproblem). Otherwise, if the pivot is in S={ai,ai+1,â€¦,aj}S =\{a_i, a_{i+1}, \dots , a_j \}S={aiâ€‹,ai+1â€‹,â€¦,ajâ€‹}ï»¿, then they do not go to the same recursive subproblem.

Thus what decides whether Xi,jX_{i,j}Xi,jâ€‹ï»¿ equals 0 or 1 is the following: it is equal to 1 iff the first time a pivot is picked in the set S, it is picked to be either aia_iaiâ€‹ï»¿ or aja_jajâ€‹ï»¿ ; otherwise Xi,j=0X_{i,j} = 0Xi,jâ€‹=0ï»¿ since ai,aja_i, a_jaiâ€‹,ajâ€‹ï»¿ will be sent separately to LLLï»¿ and RRRï»¿ and never have a chance to be compared again. Thus P(Xi,j=1)=2/(jâˆ’i+1)\mathbb{P}(X_{i,j} = 1) = 2/(j âˆ’ i + 1)P(Xi,jâ€‹=1)=2/(jâˆ’i+1)ï»¿.

Doing some algebraic manipulation

Freivaldsâ€™ Algorithm

How do we verify computation correctness?

Freivaldsâ€™ algorithm specifically focuses on verifying matrix-matrix multiplication.
